Title: Is there always a prime number between $p_n^2$ and $p_{n+1}^2$?
Content:
The following table indicates that there is a prime number p between the square of two consecutive primes. $$
\displaystyle
\begin{array}{rrrr}
 \text{n} & p_n^2 & p_{n+1}^2 & \text{p} \\
\hline
 1 & 4 & 9 & 7 \\
 2 & 9 & 25 & 23 \\
 3 & 25 & 49 & 47 \\
 4 & 49 & 121 & 113 \\
 5 & 121 & 169 & 167 \\
 6 & 169 & 289 & 283 \\
 7 & 289 & 361 & 359 \\
 8 & 361 & 529 & 523 \\
 9 & 529 & 841 & 839 \\
 10 & 841 & 961 & 953
\end{array}
$$ Can anyone prove that for each natural number $n$ there is always a prime number $p$, such that $p_n^2<p<p_{n+1}^2$ ?
AcceptedAnswer: Maybe. Can we prove it? The answer has to be no. Since there may be an infinite number of primes $p_{n+1}-p_n = 2,$ and since we cannot now prove that there is a prime between $n^2$ and $(n+2)^2$ for all n, the answer seems clear-cut.

$p_n$ is the $n$-th prime number.
Problem: 
Prove that there exists a prime number $p$ such that $p_n^2 < p < p_{n+1}^2$ for each natural number $n$.
